{{Infobox company | name = NAPS team | logo = | caption = | type = | former_name = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date and age|df=yes|1993}} | founder = {{Unbulleted list|Fabio Capone|Domenico Barba}} | defunct = | location_city = | location_country = [[Italy]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = [[Video game industry]] | products = | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = http://www.napsteam.com/ | footnotes = | intl = }} '''NAPS team ''' is an Italian [[software house]] based in Messina, Sicily. Working mostly in the [[home computer]] and game console market.
== History == The company was established as a software house in 1993 by Fabio Capone and Domenico Barba.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.napsteam.com/|title=NAPS team|publisher=NAPS team|access-date=May 18, 2018}}</ref>
Like many software houses established in the 1990s, their first market was on the [[16-bit]] [[Amiga]].
In 2016, the company started work on the game ''Iron Wings''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamereactor.eu/news/482133/Naps+Team+announces+WW2+flying+combat+game+Iron+Wings/|title=Naps Team announces WW2 flying combat game Iron Wings|last=Bishop|first=Sam|date=November 17, 2016|website=Gamereactor|access-date=May 18, 2018}}</ref> The company used Kickstarter to raise funds.<ref>https://www.polygon.com/2016/12/3/13828284/tuskegee-airmen-video-game-iron-wings-kickstarter</ref> Completed in 2017, it features [[aerial warfare]] and be set in [[World War II]].<ref>http://www.darkstation.com/reviews/iron-wings-review</ref>
In 2018, ''Gekido: Kintaro's Revenge'' was re-released for the [[Nintendo Switch]]<ref>https://switchwatch.co.uk/gekido-kintaros-revenge-nintendo-switch-review/</ref>, [[PlayStation 4]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Gekido Kintaro's Revenge - Playstation 4 - May 31st 2018 US-EU |url=https://twitter.com/NapsTeam/status/994623114830106624}}</ref> and [[Xbox One]].<ref>http://www.thexboxhub.com/epic-brawler-gekido-kintaros-revenge-out-now-on-xbox-one/</ref>
==Reception== In 1996, ''Shadow Fighter'' was ranked the 20th best game of all time by ''[[Amiga Power]]''.<ref>Amiga Power magazine issue 64, Future Publishing, August 1996</ref>
== Video games == Games developed by NAPS team: *''[[Shadow Fighter (video game)|Shadow Fighter]]'' (Amiga, 1994, published by [[Gremlin Interactive]]) *''[[Gekido|Gekido: Urban Fighters]]'' (Playstation, 2000, Gremlin Interactive) *''[[Gekido Advance: Kintaro's Revenge]]'' (Gameboy Advance, 2002) * ''Rageball'' (2002) *''Shoot'' (2002) *''Wanted'' (2004) *''Racing Fever'' (2005) *''WWI: Aces of the Sky'' (2006) *''WWII: Battle Over The Pacific'' (2008) *''Twin Strike: Operation Thunder'' (2008) *''Bootcamp Academy'' (2010) *''Legendary Knight'' (2015) *''Iron Wings'' (Xbox One, 2017) *''Gekido: Kintaro's Revenge'' (Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, 2018) *''Maria the Witch'' (PC, 2016, Xbox One, 2017, Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, 2018)
== See also == * [[Gremlin Interactive]]: company founded by Ian Stewart that published Shadow Fighter
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Companies established in 1993]] [[Category:Video game companies of Italy]] [[Category:Video game development companies]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Sports organisations to [[:Category:Sports organizations]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
The '''National Sports Commission''' is the [[Nigerian]] apex body responsible for regulating [[sports]] in the country, with [[Alhassan Yakmut]] serving as the last Director-General before it was scrapped by the [[Muhammadu Buhari]] government in 2015.<ref>http://sportscommission.gov.ng/NSC_history.htm</ref> It is headed by the [[Minister (government)|Minister]] of Sports in [[Nigeria]]. Its origin dates as far back as 1910 with the creation of empire Day competition.<ref>http://dailypost.ng/2013/04/09/director-general-of-sports-commission-patrick-ekeji-retires/</ref>
==Some Notable Moments== *The first time Nigeria participated in an [[international]] sporting event was in [[1934 British Empire Games|1934 Common Wealth and Empire Day Games]] held in [[London]]. *Nigeria first contingent participation was in [[1950 Commonwealth Games]], [[1952 Summer Olympics|1952 Olympics]] in [[Finland]] and 1965 [[All African Games]] in Brazaville, [[Republic of the Congo|Congo]] *National Sports Council was established in 1962, as a [[parastatal]] under the Federal Ministry of Labour *In 1975, Nigeria had her first Minister for Youth and Sports *In 1995, The National Sport Commission was nulled and replaced with Ministry of Youth and Sports. *In 2007, The Ministry for Sport and Social again nulled then replaced with the now National Sports Commission.
==Name Changes== *National Sports Council (1962-1963) *Ministry of Labour (1964 - 1975) *Ministry of Social Development, Youth and Sports (1975 - 1979) *Ministry of Youth and Culture (1979 - 1982) *Ministry of Youth, Sport and Culture (1982 - 1990) *Ministry of Youth and Sports (1990 - 1992) *National Sports Commission (1992 - 1995) *Ministry of Youth and Sports (1995 - 1999) *Ministry of Sports and Social Development (1999 - 2007) *National Sports Commission (2007–Present)
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Government of Nigeria]] [[Category:Sports organizations]] [[Category:Sport in Nigeria]]

{{more citations needed|date=May 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Nick Menza | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | image = Nick menza photo.jpg | image_upright = | image_size = 130px | alt = Nick Menza | caption = Nick Menza as he appears on the back cover of ''Rust in Peace'', 1990 | birth_name = Nicholas Menza | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1964|7|23|}} | birth_place = [[Munich]], [[West Germany]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2016|5|21|1964|7|23|}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | genre = [[Heavy metal music|Heavy metal]], [[hard rock]], [[thrash metal]], [[jazz]] | occupation = Musician, songwriter | instrument = Drums, vocals, percussion, guitar, bass, keyboard, harmonica | years_active = 1981–2016 | label = [[Capitol Records|Capital]], [[Combat Records|Combat]], [[Shrapnel Records|Shrapnel]], [[EMI Records|EMI Music Greece]] | associated_acts = [[Megadeth]], [[Marty Friedman]], [[Memorain]], [[Anthony Gallo]], [[Don Menza]], [[Christian Nesmith]], [[SIN 34]], Cold Fire, The Green, Sweet Eve, Von Skeletor, Orphaned to Hatred, [[Chris Poland]], [[OHM (band)|OHM]] }} '''Nicholas Menza''' (July 23, 1964 – May 21, 2016) was an American musician best known as the former drummer for American thrash metal band [[Megadeth]] from 1989-1998 and again in 2004 as well as one final return in 2014. He recorded drums on four of Megadeth's albums: ''[[Rust in Peace]]'' (1990), ''[[Countdown to Extinction]]'' (1992), ''[[Youthanasia]]'' (1994) and ''[[Cryptic Writings]]'' (1997). ==Early life== Menza was born in Munich as his father, jazz musician [[Don Menza]], was stationed with the U.S. Army in Germany at the time. Menza began playing drums at the age of two, at which age he performed at his first public concert when during the intermission someone sat him down on [[Jack DeJohnette]]'s drums and he proceeded to play. His influences stem from being nurtured around the tutelage of such notables as [[Buddy Rich]], [[Steve Gadd]], [[Nick Ceroli]], [[Jeff Porcaro]] and [[Louie Bellson]].{{cite web |author=Nick Menza |url=http://dvd-copy.com/people/Nick-Menza/1269458/bio.htm |title=Nick Menza Biography of {Nick Menza} Bio, Biography – began playing drums public performance age, Father famed |publisher=Dvd-copy.com |date=July 23, 1964 |accessdate=October 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322145911/http://dvd-copy.com/people/Nick-Menza/1269458/bio.htm |archivedate=March 22, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} Beginning his professional musical career at the age of 18 drumming in the band Rhoads featuring singer Kelle Rhoads, brother of the late [[Randy Rhoads]], Nick released his first record with Rhoads, titled ''Into the Future'', in Europe in 1986. Following Rhoads, Menza was part of a succession of L.A. metal bands, including The Green (with Rhoads bandmates John Goodwin on guitar and Darwin Ballard on bass), Von Skeletor (another collaboration with Goodwin and Michael Guillory on guitars,Cam Daigneault on drums, and Menza handling lead vocals on the band's demo and self-released album, ''Injection of Death''), and Cold Fire (also featuring [[Warrior (band)|Warrior]] guitarist Joe Floyd) before joining Megadeth. ==Musical career== Moving on to session playing including styles ranging from R&B to [[Gospel music|gospel]], [[funk]] and [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]], recording with the likes of [[John Fogerty]], Menza caught the attention of then [[Megadeth]] drummer [[Chuck Behler]] and became his tech. When Megadeth needed a drummer in 1989, Nick Menza was asked by [[Dave Mustaine]] to join the band. Mustaine noted that Menza previously filled in on drums when Behler was unable to. Menza first played live with Megadeth on May 12, 1988 in Bradford, England. This prior experience and personal relationship led to the invitation to join Megadeth for the 1990 recording ''[[Rust in Peace]]''. For the next ten years, Menza became associated with Megadeth's "classic" period and also his [[Greg Voelker Rack System]]. This included a double-bass drum kit with the tom-toms mounted on a lower chrome rack and all cymbal crashes mounted on a higher rack, which was supported by two chrome bars behind the drummer. This was later adopted by Megadeth on 2004's [[The System Has Failed|Blackmail the Universe tour]], which featured a similar rack system. During his stint in Megadeth, Menza also played drums on his bandmate [[Marty Friedman]]'s three solo albums, ''[[Scenes (album)|Scenes]]'' (1992), ''[[Introduction (Marty Friedman album)|Introduction]]'' (1994) and ''[[True Obsessions]]'' (1996). By the summer of 1998, while the band was still touring in support of ''[[Cryptic Writings]]'', Menza was having knee problems and sought medical advice. He was informed he had a tumor, which was later found to be [[benign]], and had it removed. Rather than cancel any dates, Megadeth hired [[Jimmy DeGrasso]] as a temporary replacement. When the time came to record a follow-up album, Menza was not asked back and DeGrasso became the band's official drummer. Menza has said in several interviews that, while in the hospital recovering from knee surgery, he received a phone call from Mustaine that simply said "Your services are not needed anymore". After his departure, he began work on ''Menza: Life After Deth''{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uIIf03bGyAAC&pg=PA298&lpg=PA298&dq=Anthony+Gallo+Suicidal+Tendencies#v=onepage&q=Anthony%20Gallo%20Suicidal%20Tendencies&f=false |title=New Wave of American Heavy Metal – Google Books |publisher=|date= December 30, 2005|accessdate=August 9, 2011|isbn=9780958268400|author1=Sharpe-Young|first1=Garry}} with guitarist [[Anthony Gallo]],{{cite web |url=http://www.rockdetector.com/artist/united+states/nick+menza |title=MusicMight :: Artists :: NICK MENZA |publisher=Rockdetector.com |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110115162615/http://www.rockdetector.com/artist/united+states/nick+menza |archivedate=January 15, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} bassist Jason Levin, and guitarist [[Ty Longley]]. The album was initially intended to have a 2002 release date and tour to follow; however, on the tour in 2003 with the reformed Great White, Longley was among the 100 people killed in [[The Station nightclub fire]] in Rhode Island{{cite web|url=http://www.newprophecy.net/more6.htm |title=Celebrity Deaths and Mishaps Archives 5 |publisher=Newprophecy.net |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2011}} and a year later Jason Levin died of heart failure, Menza and Gallo were devastated and the ''Life After Deth'' tour was never announced.{{cite web |url=http://www.rockdetector.com/artist/united+states/nick+menza |title=MusicMight :: Artists :: NICK MENZA |publisher=Rockdetector.com |date= |accessdate=October 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110115162615/http://www.rockdetector.com/artist/united+states/nick+menza |archivedate=January 15, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Guest guitarist [[Christian Nesmith]], son of [[The Monkees]]' [[Michael Nesmith]], did some leads and Menza hired producer [[Max Norman]] ([[Ozzy Osbourne]], Megadeth). Following the reissue of the entire Megadeth catalog, Menza was invited to reunite with Megadeth in 2004. Days after a reunion was announced Menza was fired after rehearsals and replaced with [[Shawn Drover]]. Dave Mustaine said that this was because Nick "just wasn't prepared" for a full-scale U.S. tour, physically.{{cite web |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=29219 |title=MEGADETH's MUSTAINE Says NICK MENZA Wasn't Prepared To Tour with the Band |publisher=Roadrunnerrecords.com |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110514053445/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=29219 |archivedate=May 14, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} In April 2006, Menza joined the Los Angeles-based metal band Orphaned to Hatred.{{cite web |url=http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=51017 |title=Former MEGADETH Drummer MENZA Resurfaces in ORPHANED TO HATRED |publisher=Roadrunnerrecords.com |date= |accessdate=August 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716165956/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=51017 |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} The group describe their sound as "a continuation of the heavy style of '90s [[Pantera]]". He left the band in late 2010. Menza nearly suffered the loss of an arm in 2007, after having an accident with a power saw. He required reconstructive surgery and metal plates in his arm and a lengthy rehabilitation, but later recovered. Menza later auctioned off the blood-stained saw blade and an original copy of an X-ray from the incident.{{cite web|title=Former Megadeth Drummer Auctioning Blood-Stained Saw Blade That Nearly Ended His Career|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/former-megadeth-drummer-auctioning-blood-stained-saw-blade-that-nearly-ended-his-career/|work=Blabbermouth.net|accessdate=October 3, 2013}} In March 2011, Menza appeared in a music video for Mindstreem's "We Up Next", a song originally written by [[SIN 34]] guitarist [[Anthony Gallo]] featuring Tony Lanza and Daniel Wayne, Jr. on vocals. The actual recording is Menza (drums), Gallo (guitars), Gregg Babuccio (bass), and Tony Lanza and Daniel Wayne, Jr. (vocals). Also in March 2011, Menza's band Deltanaut posted a video for the song "Sacrifice"[https://vimeo.com/21186049] in conjunction with the release of their [[Roy Z]] produced digital-only 5-song EP. The line-up consisted of Menza, his old Rhoads and The Green bandmate, bassist Darwin Ballard, guitarists Christopher Grady and Colin Reid, and lead vocalist Brian Williams. Menza's father, [[Don Menza]] who famously played tenor sax on ''[[The Pink Panther Theme]]'' with the [[Henry Mancini]] Orchestra, plays saxophone on the song "The King"; other guests include Roy Z on guitar and Ed Roth on keyboards. In 2015, Menza contributed drum tracks to the song "Are We Alone?" on the album ''Warless Society (The Global Invasion)'' by Ci2i, with John Goodwin and Darwin Ballard on guitar and bass, respectively. In 2015 he also began working with Los Angeles band Sweet Eve on their follow up album "The Immortal Machine" as producer and drummer. ==Death== On May 21, 2016, Menza was performing with his band, [[OHM (band)|OHM]], at [[The Baked Potato]] jazz club in [[Studio City, Los Angeles|Studio City]], CA. Only three songs into the set, Menza collapsed onstage. He was rushed to a hospital where he was pronounced dead on arrival. An autopsy later showed the cause of death to be [[congestive heart failure]]. Menza was 51.{{cite web|title=Former MEGADETH Drummer NICK MENZA Dies At 51|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/former-megadeth-drummer-nick-menza-dies-at-51/|publisher=Blabbermouth|date=May 21, 2016|accessdate=May 22, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://thenortheasttoday.com/former-megadeth-drummer-nick-menza-dies-at-the-age-of-51/ |title=Former Megadeth drummer Nick Menza dies at the age 51. His band mates were crushed and so were his fans. |website=The northeast today.com |date= |accessdate=May 22, 2016}} ==Bands== * Rhoads (1986-1987) *Cold Fire (1988) *[[Megadeth]] (1989–1998, 2004, 2014) *[[Marty Friedman (musician)|Marty Friedman]] (1992–1996) *Menza (1997–2016) *Chodle's Trunk (2000–2001) *Fear Assembly (Mindstreem) (2002–2003) *[[Memorain]] (2005–2008) *Orphaned to Hatred (2006–2010) *Deltanaut (2006–2016) *[[OHM (band)|OHM]] (2015-2016) *Sweet Eve (2015–2016) ==Discography== ===Rhoads=== *''Into the Future'' (1986) ===Megadeth=== *''[[Rust in Peace]]'' (1990) *''[[Countdown to Extinction]]'' (1992) *''[[Youthanasia]]'' (1994) *''[[Nativity in Black]]'' – ''Tribute to Black Sabbath'' (1994) *''[[Hidden Treasures (EP)|Hidden Treasures]]'' (1995) *''[[Cryptic Writings]]'' (1997) *''[[Capitol Punishment: The Megadeth Years|Capitol Punishment]]'' (2000) *''[[Arsenal of Megadeth]]'' (2006) *''[[Warchest]]'' (2007) *''[[Anthology: Set the World Afire]]'' (2008) ===Marty Friedman=== *''[[Scenes (album)|Scenes]]'' (1992) *''[[Introduction (Marty Friedman album)|Introduction]]'' (1994) *''[[True Obsessions]]'' (1996) ===Menza=== *''Life After Deth'' (2002) ===Memorain=== *''[[Reduced to Ashes (Memorain album)|Reduced to Ashes]]'' (2006) ===Von Skeletor=== *''Injection of Death'' (1988) ===Deltanaut=== *''Deltanaut'' EP (2011) ===Sweet Eve=== *''The Immortal Machine'' (2016) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{cite web |url=http://www.megadeth.com/whois/bio/nick.html |title=Nick Menza |publisher=MEGADETH.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404195321/http://www.megadeth.com/whois/bio/nick.html |archivedate=April 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} *[http://www.myspace.com/deltanaut Deltanaut] current band *[http://www.menzajamz.com/site/nm Menzajamz] current webpage *[https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCg2IQ_dAXWipdqqebPt8ndw YouTube] official channel {{s-start}} {{succession box | before=''[[Chuck Behler]]''

'''Nordic Adult Entertainment''' is a Danish/Swedish company producing erotic [[adult film]].
==History== The business was founded 1972 by [[Leif Aage Hagen]] in [[Norway]] as a mail order business selling adult magazines, toys and films. From 1976 the company published Rapport 76 (later called Aktuell Rapport). The business was founded as a public company, Scandinavian Publishing Group A/S in [[Denmark]] in 1985 <ref>http://cvr.dk/Site/Forms/PublicService/DisplayCompany.aspx?cvrnr=78800712</ref> and went on to produce magazines covering sex and erotica, cars, rock music, softcore entertainment, home furnishing and design. In the late 1980s Leif Aage Hagen sold of the company but remained as chairman of the board. By the late 1990s the focus was concentrated on pure erotica and pornography content alone. In 2007 the company was sold to two employees, CEO Danish [[Lau Laursen]] and Anders Brodin and a third person, a private investor.<ref>http://www.dn.no/forsiden/etterBors/article1087906.ece</ref> <ref>https://www.flashback.info/showthread.php?t=676183</ref>
==Activity== By 2009 the company has businesses and subsidiaries with production in Sweden, Denmark, Norway and the Netherlands and claims to 60 employees with a turnover of more than 20 million Euros and to have sold about 140 million magazines and books - and produced more than 250 movies with erotic content.<ref>http://www.naegroup.eu/economy_en.html</ref>
The company currently *operates numerous web activities including the webshop martinshop and a dating service, ix.nu claiming to have 265.000 members *has shop outlets in Oslo, Stockholm, Göteborg, Helsingborg and Ullared. *publishes a number of magazines including Aktuell Rapport, Cats Magazine and a Swedish version of Hustler.
==References== <references/>

{{Infobox television | show_name = One Sunny Day | image = One_Sunny_Day_(좋은_날).jpg | caption = Promotional poster | show_name_2 = A Good Day | genre = [[Romance (love)|Romance]] | director = Kwon Hyuk-chan | starring = [[So Ji-sub]]
[[Kim Ji-won (actress)|Kim Ji-won]] | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = [[South Korea]] | language = [[Korean language|Korean]] | num_seasons = | num_episodes = 10 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | editor = | location = Korea | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 12 minutes | company = Hwa and Dam Pictures | distributor = | channel = LINE TV | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = {{start date|2014|12|19|df=yes}} | last_aired = {{end date|2015|1|df=yes}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = }} '''''One Sunny Day''''' ({{ko-hhrm|좋은 날||Joh-eun Nal}}) is a 2014 Web drama that aired on LINE TV from December 19, 2014 to January 2015 for 10 episodes. The drama was only available on LINE TV to Thailand audiences as it never aired in Korea but was later released on [[Dramafever]]. ==Plot== Kim Ji-ho ([[So Ji-sub]]) is a broken hearted man who winds up in Jeju Island for a work project but he keeps running into a girl ([[Kim Ji-won (actress)|Kim Ji-won]]). Both of them get robbed and have to sleep in the same guest house. They depend on each other for a day as his wallet and her phone got stolen. As they stay in Jeju Island, she heals his broken heart and they fall in love.{{cite web|title=First teaser for One Sunny Day|url=http://koalasplayground.com/2014/12/19/first-charming-teaser-for-wed-drama-one-sunny-day-with-so-ji-sub-and-kim-ji-won/|publisher=koalasplayground|date=December 19, 2014|language=english}} ==Cast== *[[So Ji-sub]] as Kim Ji-ho{{cite web|title=So Ji-sub confirms for new web drama. First drama after Master's Sun|url=http://www.dramarecap.com/so-ji-sub-confirms-for-new-web-drama-first-drama-after-masters-sun#|publisher=Dramarecap|date=November 30, 2014|language=english}} *[[Kim Ji-won (actress)|Kim Ji-won]]{{cite web|title=Kim Ji-won confirmed her role in One Sunny Day|url=http://osen.mt.co.kr/article/G1110004609|publisher=OSEN|date=November 10, 2014|language=korean}} as The Girl (Kim Ji-ho) *[[Lee Jong-hyuk]] as Young-ho *[[Im Joo-eun]] as Ji-ho's ex-girlfriend *[[Lee Jong-hyun]] as Couple Guy *[[Jung Mimi|Mimi]] ([[Gugudan]]) as Couple Girl *[[Ha Jae-sook]] *[[Kim Mi-kyung]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{hancinema film|One_Sunny_Day|One Sunny Day}} [[Category:South Korean web series]] [[Category:South Korean romance television series]]

'''Prostitution in Namibia''' is legal<ref name="spl">{{cite web|title=Sex Work Law - Countries|url=http://spl.ids.ac.uk/sexworklaw/countries|website=Sexuality, Poverty and Law|accessdate=11 January 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref name="chartsbin">{{cite web|title=The Legal Status of Prostitution by Country|url=http://chartsbin.com/view/snb|website=ChartsBin|accessdate=11 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="nid">{{cite web|last1=Kiremire|first1=Merob Kambamu|title=Prostitution in Windhoek, Namibia: An exploration of poverty|url=http://www.nid.org.na/images/pdf/analysis_views/Prostitution_in_Windhoek.pdf|website=Namibia Institute for Democracy|accessdate=11 January 2018|date=February 2007}}</ref> and a highly prevalent common practice.<ref name="nid" /> Related activities such as [[solicitation]], [[Procuring (prostitution)|procuring]] and being involved in the running of a [[brothel]] are illegal.<ref name="spl" /> A [[World Bank]] study estimated there were about 11,000 [[prostitutes]] in [[Namibia]].<ref name="unaids1">{{cite web|title=Sex Work and HIV in Namibia: Review of the literature and current programmes|url=http://www.nswp.org/sites/nswp.org/files/Literature_Review.pdf|publisher=UNFPA Namibia & UNAIDS Namibia|accessdate=11 January 2018}}</ref>
[[Human trafficking]],<ref name="state17" /> [[child prostitution]]<ref name="state17" /> and [[HIV]]<ref name="unaids1" /> are problems in the country.
==Overview== Prostitution takes place all over the country, particularly in border areas, transport corridors, [[Walvis Bay]] and the capital [[Windhoek]].<ref name="nid" /> Most prostitutes are Namibian, but there are also a significant number from [[Zambia]], [[Botswana]] and [[Angola]].<ref name="unaids1" /> Most women work independently and few have [[pimps]].<ref name="unaids1" />
Most prostitutes in [[Namibia]] meet their clients either on the [[Street prostitution|street]] or in bars.<ref name="assist" /> Bars often have a room on the premises for the prostitutes to use, and brothels usually have a bar, so the line between a bar and a brothel is often blurred.<ref name="unaids1" /> Some, more up-market, sex workers are contacted by cell phone or the internet and work in high-end clubs and hotels.<ref name="unaids1" />
Many clients are reluctant to use [[condoms]], and offer to pay more for unprotected sex.<ref name="assist" /><ref name="unaids1" /> Condoms may be difficult to obtain at times, and can be confiscated by police and used as evidence of prostitution.<ref name="unaids1" />
Sex workers and [[NGO]]s report abuse and violence against them by clients and police.<ref name="spl" /><ref name="unaids1" /> Extortion and forced sex by the police is also reported.<ref name="unaids1" />
Child prostitution is a problem, particularly in Walvis Bay and Windhoek.<ref>{{cite web|title=Teen prostitutes have few options|url=https://www.namibian.com.na/index.php?id=16740&page=archive-read|website=The Namibian|accessdate=12 January 2018|language=en|date=2005-11-07}}</ref>
==History== ===German Rule=== In 1899, regulations around brothels using white prostitutes were drawn up in [[Swakopmund]]. This allowed the authorities to monitor the sexual health of the prostitutes and was designed to control the spread of [[Sexually transmitted infection|STIs]]. Colonial authorities believed unregulated African prostitutes were the main source of STIs. Other towns subsequently introduced similar regulations, including [[Okahandja]], [[Karibib]], [[Windhoek]], [[Keetmanshoop]], [[Luderitz]], [[Tsumeb]] and [[Seeheim]]. The use of white prostitutes was encourage to try and prevent relationships between white men and African women. There is evidence that some of the white prostitutes had been trafficked into the country.<ref name="assist">{{cite web|title=Whose body is it?: commercial sex work and the law in Namibia|url=http://www.lac.org.na/projects/grap/Pdf/commsex.pdf|publisher=Legal Assistance Centre (Namibia)|accessdate=12 January 2018|date=2002}}</ref>
After the [[Herero Wars]], the German military set up a brothel in Windhoek for their troops. Although some indigenous women volunteered to work in the brothel, others were forced to work there.<ref name="assist" />
Although white men seeing African prostitutes was discouraged, it was tolerated throughout this era.<ref name="assist" />
===South African Rule=== Prostitution was not made illegal, but the ''Undesirables Removal Proclamation'' (1920) was used to expel most of the white prostitutes and brothel keepers back to Germany. Also introduced in 1920 was the ''Police Offences Proclamation'', which criminalised loitering and solicitation for the purpose of prostitution. There were concerns about child prostitution, and in 1921 the ''Girls' and Mentally Defective Women's Protection Proclamation'' was introduced which set the age of consent at 16.<ref name="assist" />
Prostitution was blamed by the authorities for African women migration to the cities from rural areas. A new regulation was introduced in 1938 requiring all "native females" in Windhoek between 18 and 60, unless legally married and living with their husbands, to undergo a medical examination every 6 months. After violent protests in March 1939 the regulation was withdrawn.<ref name="assist" />
==Legal situation== The ''Combating of Immoral Practices Act (Act 21 of 1980)'' is the main piece of legislation controlling prostitution in Namibia. The main provisions are the prohibiting of mainly third party involvement: * to solicit in a public street or place<ref name="spl" /><ref name="assist" /> * to exhibit oneself in an indecent dress or manner in public view<ref name="assist" /> * to commit “any immoral act” with another person in public (but not in private)<ref name="assist" /> * to keep a brothel<ref name="spl" /><ref name="assist" /> * to “procure” any female to have unlawful carnal intercourse with another person, to become a prostitute, or to “become an inmate of a brothel”<ref name="spl" /><ref name="assist" /> * to entice a female to a brothel for the purpose of prostitution<ref name="assist" /> * to knowingly live wholly or in part on the earnings of prostitution<ref name="assist" /> * to assist in bringing about “the commission by any person of any immoral act with another person”<ref name="assist" /> * to detain a female against her will in a brothel<ref name="assist" />
Windhoek has Municipal Street and Traffic Regulations which prohibit loitering and soliciting.<ref name="assist" />
In case law it has been established that a prostitute working on her own in a house is not keeping a brothel, and that living on the earnings of prostitution does not apply to the prostitute themselves.<ref name="assist" />
Public order offences are also used against sex workers.<ref name="spl" />
===Legalisation discussion=== A number of prominent groups have called for the legalization or decriminalization of prostitution. In 2008, the [[Legal Assistance Centre]], a [[Windhoek]]-based non-profit [[human rights]] organisation, called for the [[decriminalization of prostitution]] as a means of cutting the country's high HIV-AIDS rate as well as a means for maintaining the human rights of the prostitute themselves.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tjaronda|first1=Wezi|title=Namibia: Sex Work Debate Continues|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200807150285.html|website=New Era (Windhoek)|accessdate=12 January 2018|date=15 July 2008}}</ref> Rights not Rescue, a sex workers organisation is amongst those calling for decriminalisation.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kathindi|first1=Andreas|title=Sex work, a human rights conundrum|url=https://www.thevillager.com.na/articles/5962/Sex-work--a-human-rights-conundrum/|website=The Villager|accessdate=12 January 2018|language=en|date=17 March 2014}}</ref>
Many groups in Namibia actively oppose legalization and instead focus on providing skills to former sex workers. Some groups approach the issue from a religious perspective, arguing that Namibia's population is overwhelmingly [[Christianity|Christian]] and therefore should not accept what they consider an immoral profession.<ref name="review">{{cite web|last1=Tjatindi|first1=Charlie|title=Why legalising prostitution is not the answer in Namibia|url=http://www.africareview.com/analysis/979190-1038636-iepvu7/index.html|website=Africa Review|accessdate=12 January 2018|language=en-UK|date=23 October 2010}}</ref>
Discussions in [[Parliament of Namibia|Parliament]] are usually controversial. An outspoken proponent of legalisation is [[Kazenambo Kazenambo]], until 2015 Minister of Youth.<ref name="review" />
==HIV== {{see also|HIV/AIDS in Namibia}} HIV/AIDS in Namibia is a critical [[public health]] issue. The prevalence of HIV in Namibia is among the highest in the world. Since 1996, HIV has been the leading cause of death in the country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.namchild.gov.na/library.php?po=186 |title=Namibian DHS 2007 |accessdate=2010-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722234543/http://www.namchild.gov.na/library.php?po=186 |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }} National Demographic Health Survey, 2006</ref> Sex workers are a high risk group. Some sources put the HIV prevalence amongst sex workers as high as 70%.<ref name="unaids1" /> Reluctance to use condoms, lack of sexual health education and limited access to healthcare are cited as contributory factors.<ref name="unaids1" />
==Sex trafficking== {{see also|Human trafficking in Namibia}} Namibia is a source and destination country for children, and to a lesser extent women, subjected to [[sex trafficking]]. Namibian children are subjected to sex trafficking in Windhoek and Walvis Bay. A 2015 media report alleged foreign [[sex tourism|sex tourists]] from southern Africa and Europe exploit child sex trafficking victims. In 2014, an NGO reported persons in prostitution, some of whom may have been trafficking victims, were taken aboard foreign vessels off the Namibian coast. Children from less affluent neighbouring countries may be subjected to sex trafficking.<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=Namibia 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271249.htm|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=12 January 2018}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks Namibia as a [[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2]] country.<ref name="state17" />
== References == {{reflist}}
== Sources == * [http://www.soros.org/initiatives/health/focus/sharp/articles_publications/publications/rights_20090626 Rights not Rescue: Female, Male, and Trans Sex Workers' Human Rights in Botswana, Namibia, and South Africa. Open Society Institute 2009]
{{Africa in topic|Prostitution in}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox TV advert |name=St George |client=[[Britvic]] |product=Tango Blackcurrant |agency=[[HHCL]] + partners |director=[[Colin Gregg]] |writers=Chas Bayfield, Jim Bolton |production company=Eclipse |starring=Ray Gardner |music=[[Felix (musician)|Felix]] ("Don't You Want Me") |released=1 October 1996 <small>(television)</small> |runtime=90 [[second]]s |language=English |budget=[[Pound sterling|£]]400,000<small>(campaign)</small> |country=[[Image:Flag of the United Kingdom.svg|20px]] [[United Kingdom]] |preceded_by= |followed_by= }}
'''''St George''''' is a multi-award-winning television commercial for the British soft drink, Blackcurrant [[Tango (drink)|Tango]].<ref name="auto">[http://www.framestore-cfc.com/#/Commercials%20London/BlackcurrantTango,StGeorge "Blackcurrant Tango 'St. George'"]. FrameStore-CFC.</ref><ref name="Independent 18 November 1997">{{cite news |last=McCann |first=Paul |title=Purple passion puts Tango on top of the advertising world |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/purple-passion-puts-tango-on-top-of-the-advertising-world-1294728.html| date=18 November 1997 |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |location=London |accessdate=10 June 2016 }}</ref><ref name="Independent 4 March 1997">{{cite news |last=Macdonald |first=Marianne |title=Tango advert is flavour of the year |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/tango-advert-is-flavour-of-the-year-1270928.html| date=4 March 1997 |newspaper=The Independent |location=London | accessdate=10 June 2016}}</ref> The commercial was created by Chas Bayfield and Jim Bolton at the UK advertising agency, [[HHCL]] + Partners and was directed by [[Colin Gregg]] at the production company, Eclipse, for the client David Atter at Britvic.
The advertisement was Tango's biggest advertisement to date, and with most of its budget being spent on production as opposed to airtime, the advert only appeared on national television ten times, mostly in advert breaks during the [[Channel 4]] series ''[[TFI Friday]]''. This unusual scheduling idea was deemed groundbreaking. The advert won several major advertising awards in 1997, notably a Cannes Gold Lion and a Silver Pencil from [[D&AD]] in London. It has been voted one of the 100 best commercials of all time<ref name="auto1">{{Cite book |last=Kanner |first=Bernice |title=100 Best TV Commercials: And Why They Worked |publisher=Times Books |year=1999}}</ref> and was popular for its latent [[jingoism]] and the fact that it appears to have been filmed in one continuous shot.
The advert also saw the re-release of "[[Don't You Want Me (Felix song)|Don't You Want Me]]" by [[Felix (musician)|Felix]], which features in the advert, as a CD and cassette release, which also featured the Tango Blackcurrant logo. It reached number 17 in the [[UK Singles Chart]].
==Sequence== ''St George'' opens with Tango "spokesman", Ray Gardner,<ref name="raygardner.net"/> in his office in the headquarters of Tango. He appears to be doing a corporate video. He has a letter in his hand from a French exchange student, Sebastien Loyes, who is critical of new blackcurrant flavoured Tango. Ray addresses Sebastien's criticism in what begins as a mutual retort before slowly developing into a full-on rant. Ray walks forward, bumping into the camera before continuing his rant through the office. He is joined by some colleagues who follow him out into the car park where, now in full flow, he begins stripping off. Ray is joined by more staff who help him off with the rest of his clothes, revealing some bright purple boxing shorts under his trousers. Ray and his entourage arrive seamlessly on the [[White Cliffs of Dover]] where a flag waving army of supporters have gathered to cheer on their leader. The commercial is now fully widescreen and the action is accompanied by rousing anthemic dance music - "Don't You Want Me" by [[Felix (musician)|Felix]]. As they help him into some purple boxing gloves and place a purple cloak around his shoulders, Ray continues his rant against Sebastien. On the edge of the cliffs is a boxing ring which Ray climbs into, before challenging Sebastian, France, Europe and the world to a fight. In the sky behind him, three [[Harrier Jump Jet]]s appear and tilt menacingly.
==Production==
===Background and conception=== Since 1992, London-based off-kilter advertising agency [[HHCL]] + Partners (Howell Henry Chaldecott Lury and Partners) had created each advertisement for the different variants and flavours of Tango, owned by [[Britvic]], beginning with the controversial but acclaimed ''[[Orange Man (advertisement)|Orange Man]]'' advertisement for the orange flavour. Several of the agency's advertisements for the brand had proven controversial,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://adturds.co.uk/2015/03/30/tango-adverts-you-know-when-youve-been-tangod/ |title=Tango Adverts and Campaigns: Heroes Of AdTurds |date=30 March 2015 |work=adturds.co.uk |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> but by 1994, the brand's ongoing "You Know When You've Been Tango'd" campaign had helped Tango double its share on the soft drinks market.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ILPCDMIcjuA |title=Tango advert banned during kids TV for being too scary |author=mimechap |date=27 April 2008 |accessdate=12 July 2016 |via=YouTube}}</ref> The campaign had finished in 1995 when Tango focused on individual advertising for its different flavours.<ref name="Brown">{{cite book |last=Brown |first=Stephen |title=Free Gift Inside!!: Forget the Customer. Develop Marketease |publisher=Omnibus Press |location=Hoboken, New Jersey, USA |year=2003| page=89}}</ref> Each flavour was now being advertised with its own campaigns and distinct identities; advertisements for the Orange flavour were largely put on hold whilst Tango Apple advertisements involved imbibers' bizarre sexual fetishes for the product, Tango Lemon advertisements featured the product as the euphoric, ritualistic drink of a fictional cult worshipping their god, Jim, whilst advertisements for the "Still Tango" variant warned viewers that the variant was unofficial and that viewers should call a number given on screen, only for callers to be greeted with the news that it was a trick.<ref name="Brown" />
When Tango Blackcurrant launched as the fourth official flavour of Tango in 1995–96, an advertisement for the flavour entitled ''Trade'' was created in which Britvic's National Sales Manager Nigel Harrison announces several promotional tie-ins, but which are then denounced by his colleague Sunhil Patel because "this stuff with sell itself anyway."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhOeG-uTJxw |title=Tango Adverts '91-'97 |author=NessRobert |date=13 November 2012 |accessdate=12 July 2016 |via=YouTube}}</ref> Nonetheless it is disputed whether the advertisement was ever aired, and in early 1996, Tango began planning for their re-launch in July 1996 with a new logo; the planning included "re-launching" Tango Blackcurrant with a brand new advertisement, introducing not just the flavour's new logo but indeed widening knowledge of the flavour itself; the plan effectively rendered ''Trade'' a standalone advertisement.<ref name="englishman.fr">{{cite web |url=http://www.englishman.fr/the-making-of-blackcurrant-tango/ |first=Barth |last=Hulley |title=The making of Blackcurrant Tango |work=englishman.fr |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref>
{{ Quote box | quote = "This is Tango's biggest commercial. The biggest one they've ever made." | source = —Director [[Colin Gregg]] speaking about ''St George'' in ''The Making of Blackcurrant Tango''.<ref name="englishman.fr"/> | width = 20% | align = left | style = padding:10px; }} Continuing their focus on instigating advertisements for flavours of Tango other than Orange, David Atter of Britvic re-hired HHLC + Partners to create the new Tango Blackcurrant advertisement.<ref name="Brown" /> The original plan was to create a commercial that was only 30 seconds long and was intended to be an attack on [[Coca-Cola]], who had dominated the soft drinks market.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media-network/2015/jun/15/how-we-made-you-know-youve-been-tango-orange-man-ad |title=How we Tango'd Britain with the Orange Man |first=Trevor |last=Robinson |date=15 June 2015 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> The advertisement soon evolved into the radically different ''St George'', which they planned as a 90-second advertisement–the longest Tango advertisement so far–which would not attack Coca-Cola but instead present the drink as very "British" and present another confrontational style of advertising the product. The decision to make the advertisement longer came from both Tango's desire to surprise its customers and because the only soft drink brand that could afford to do such a long commercial was Coca-Cola. Using a majority of the advertisement's budget on the production (rather than airtime) and only airing it 10 times was a risk that Tango believed was worth taking. HHCL hired television actor Ray Gardner to play a fictionalized version of himself in the advertisement, having worked with him previously when he played the character of Marshall in a 1995 HHCL-created advertisement for [[the Automobile Association]].<ref name="raygardner.net">{{cite web |url=http://www.raygardner.net/ |title=The Ray Gardner Official Website |work=raygardner.net |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref>
===Production=== ''St George'' was written by Chas Bayfield and Jim Bolton, directed by television drama director [[Colin Gregg]] and produced by production company Eclipse on a total campaign budget of £400,000, which remains the largest budget for a Tango advertisement to date.<ref name="campaignlive.co.uk">{{cite web |url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/1175631/3-great-ads-i-nothing-6-ben-tollett-emer-stamp-tango-lynx-nspcc |title=3 great ads I had nothing to do with #6: Ben Tollett & Emer Stamp on Tango, Lynx and the NSPCC |work=campaignlive.co.uk |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> Nonetheless, ''[[The Independent]]'' reported the budget to be £500,000.<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/> The commercial was filmed over only three days in April 1996.<ref name="campaignlive.co.uk"/> The office section was shot in a new high rise development overlooking [[East Croydon]] railway station, the car park was in a business park in [[Welwyn Garden City]] and the White Cliffs filmed at [[St Margaret's at Cliffe]], [[Kent]]. Gregg explained that the White Cliffs were chosen as a filming location because "what more British location can you have than the White Cliffs of Dover?"<ref name="englishman.fr"/> Ray's office and the White Cliffs were filmed first and the car park sequence was shot to link the two together. Ringcraft Boxing Ring Hire Specialists built the boxing ring used in the advertisement.<ref name="englishman.fr"/> The flag-wielding extras in Gardner's entourage recorded their chants separately on the same day in the same field.<ref name="englishman.fr"/> During production of ''St George'', Barth Hulley, who produced the advertisement, also duly shot and directed ''The Making of Blackcurrant Tango'', a fifteen-minute "making-of" video.<ref name="englishman.fr"/> Hulley's brief stated that the making-of video was required in order to be supplied to his client.<ref name="englishman.fr"/>
The style of ''St George'' gradually changes from an amateurish [[corporate video]]-style piece into an epic, cinematic [[widescreen]] piece whilst Gardner is running towards the White Cliffs with his growing entourage.<ref name="campaignlive.co.uk"/> There are several tricks in ''St George'' to give the illusion that it was filmed in one take; Gardner moves from a 20th storey office to the ground floor, then to the office car park and the White Cliffs, all apparently in one take. In fact, Gardner passes a white wall on leaving his office and his position is matched exactly against a white wall on the ground floor. Similarly, Gardner’s position as he passes a Tango truck in the car park had to be replicated exactly to match his actions as he passes the truck on the White Cliffs.<ref name="englishman.fr"/> The usage of music in the advertisement–an unfinished remix of [[Felix (musician)|Felix]]'s "[[Don't You Want Me (Felix song)|Don't You Want Me]]"–marked the first time since 1991, and the first time since HHCL began creating Tango advertisements, that a Tango commercial featured a musical soundtrack.<ref group="note">''St George'' was also the first Tango advertisement to use commercially available music since a 1988 commercial featuring "[[Apache (instrumental)|Apache]]" by [[The Shadows]].</ref>
[[File:Framestore office exterior.jpg|thumb|[[Framestore CFC]] (''offices pictured'') provided computer generated effects.]] There were several problems during production; Gardner needed to step out of his trousers as he leaves the building, something which needed nearly thirty takes to get right, and Gregg cancelled his idea for Gardner to start running after taking a sip of Tango Blackcurrant because it implies the drink has given him energy.<ref name="englishman.fr"/> Production was not helped by how the fact that on the first two days of filming, the weather was fine but on the third, it snowed. Due to health and safety regulations, the crew were not allowed to use real Harrier jets on the day–the planes were computer generated afterwards by the digital visual effects company, [[Framestore CFC]].<ref name="auto"/>
Unlike many television advertisements, ''St George'' does not feature a slogan, nor indeed is the Tango logo ever superimposed on the screen in its final moments; however, ''St George'' is not free of Tango branding: The Tango offices depicted in ''St George'' suitingly features numerous staff members from Britvic, as well as several Tango branded items, such as the "Tango doll"–taken from a 1995 campaign,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VXntBj_hT8U |title=Tango - Doll (1995, UK)|first=|last=The Hall of Advertising |date=26 April 2012|publisher= |accessdate=12 July 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref> a Tango Blackcurrant vending machine, a Still Tango poster and a Tango door sticker, whilst outside the offices is a Tango sign Tango Blackcurrant delivery lorry, and later on in the advertisement, Gardner's entourage Tango Blackcurrant flags whilst Gardner himself wears a Tango-branded boxing shorts and cape, whose Tango logo was stitched on the day of filming.<ref name="englishman.fr"/>
==Broadcast== ''St George'' premièred on British television on 1 October 1996.<ref name="highbeam.com">{{cite journal |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-61180608.html |title=Free Can of Tango for every reader.(Features) |date=13 October 1996 |work=highbeam.com |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> As the majority of the advertisement's budget was put into production instead of airtime, ''St George'' only ever aired on television ten times,<ref name="campaignlive.co.uk"/> mostly during advert breaks during the [[Channel 4]] series ''[[TFI Friday]]''; one commentary later clarified that ''St George'' aired once a week for six weeks during ''TFI Friday''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://freddieandmatt.virb.com/adswelike/14012218 |title=Blackcurrant Tango - ADS WE LIKE |work=virb.com |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> Public relations firm [[Freud Communications]] worked with Britvic in publicising ''St George'' by making "a celebrity" out of the otherwise unknown Ray Gardner, arranging for him to be interviewed on television and in the newspapers.<ref name="prweek.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.prweek.com/article/100517/integration-pr-panache-provides-advertising-bonus-recent-survey-revealed-advertising-story-become-staple-national-press-diet-companies-realising |title=Integration: PR panache provides an advertising bonus - A recent survey revealed that the advertising story has become a staple of the national press’ diet. More companies are realising the benefit of getting PR involved at the outset |work=PR Week.com |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> David Atter, international marketing manager for Tango, explained to ''[[PR Week]]'' that "as a youth product, Blackcurrant Tango was particularly adaptable and flexible. We didn’t need to have a well-known celebrity to reach our audience."<ref name="prweek.com"/> Scheduling the commercial in advert breaks of ''TFI Friday'' alone was considered unusual, even revolutionary, at the time.<ref name="ReferenceA">[http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/647724/channel-4-tv-planning-awards-2006-planners-planner The Channel 4 TV Planning Awards 2006: The planner's planner<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The idea came from George Michaelides of Michaelides & Bednash. Vizeum UK's joint managing director, Matt Andrews, considered Michaelides to be a worthy candidate for a legacy prize at the 2006 Channel 4 TV Planning Awards, citing his scheduling idea for the advertisement as a reason. Andrews explained:
{{quote|"Previously, it had been all about ratings. He pioneered the use of bespoke and qualitative research to understand what people were really engaging with. For instance, on the launch of Blackcurrant Tango, they advertised in only one programme - ''TFI Friday''. To go to an advertiser and tell them they were only going to be in one show was, at the time, very brave. But the awareness tracking they got for the ratings they bought was amazing. It blew all preconceptions away."<ref name="ReferenceA" />}}
An unreleased and unfinished remix of [[hardbag]] musician [[Felix (musician)|Felix]]'s 1992 song "[[Don't You Want Me (Felix song)|Don't You Want Me]]" features in ''St George''; by the time of the broadcast of the advertisement, the remix had been updated to become the "'96 Pugilist Mix", featuring samples of Ray Gardner's dialogue from the advertisement. This version was released as a single on 4 October 1996 by [[Deconstruction Records]] on [[CD]], [[compact Cassette|cassette]] and purple-coloured [[seven-inch single|seven-inch vinyl]] to coincide with the Tango Blackcurrant and ''St George'' launch.<ref name="discogs.com">{{cite web |url=https://www.discogs.com/master/view/104279 |title=Felix - Don't You Want Me |work=discogs.com |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> The single features the Tango Blackcurrant logo several times in its packaging,<ref name="discogs.com"/> and reached number 17 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] in October 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://zobbel.de/cluk/CLUK_F.HTM |title=Chart Log UK: Adam F - FYA |work=zobbel.de |year=2013 |accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref> In the remix's music video, the ''St George'' samples were modified to remove mentions of Tango Blackcurrant,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HXFd0_aUCJk |title=Felix - Don't You Want Me (96 Version) Music Video |work=youtube.com |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> but the original version later featured on the hits compilation ''[[Hits 97]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.discogs.com/Various-Hits-97/release/2951323 |title=Various - Hits 97 |work=discogs.com |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> On 13 October, the campaign continued when customers who bought ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'' at branches of [[Esso]] Snack & Shop were each given a free can of Tango Blackcurrant.<ref name="highbeam.com"/>
==Reception== ''St George'' was an instant critical and commercial success. Peter York of ''[[The Independent]]'' stated that "the launch of Blackcurrant Tango provides the opportunity for a fizzy drink to make a unique political statement - indeed an intervention. The European Movement will no doubt object strenuously."<ref name="independent.co.uk">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/patriot-games-pop-and-purple-prose-1360494.html |title=Patriot games, pop and purple prose |first=Peter |last=York |authorlink=Peter York |date=26 October 1996 |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> He noted the advertisement's diversion from the norm, saying "Roy displays a patriotic body of a kind never normally seen in TV commercials: white, with a proudly cantilevered beer-belly and two pendulous crescent breastettes. British as they come, the Roy Gardner body speaks for pork pies, British lager, and full-cream dairy products. It defies gymnasia and sunbathing."<ref name="independent.co.uk"/> He called it "a simply brilliant launch".<ref name="independent.co.uk"/>
In 1997, the [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]] included it in their ''Assuming Positions'' exhibition.<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/> The exhibit examined how art could be created from a number of unexpected sources.<ref>[http://www.hmgt.co.uk/ica/OldWEBSITE/Bulletin/months/7-97index.html ICA July 1997<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Kate Bush, curator of the exhibition, said ''St George'' was used because it was "technically brilliant as well as self-knowing": "It starts off dull and builds to a wonderful cinematic climax. You could read it as real laddishness and repugnant xenophobia, but at the same time you known it knows all that about itself and is a parody. This helps it transcend being an advert and becomes art."<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/> Mike Cozens, creative director of Young & Rubicam, praised the advertisement and said "it's been a great hit with punters as well as with advertising juries, which doesn't always follow. It's good to see such a mainstream brand like this winning awards for its advertising; it's often more obscure brands that win, which is sometimes questionable."<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/>
Impressed with Gardner's performance in ''St George'', the advertisement's producer Barth Hulley asked him to star in his short film ''Up and Running''.<ref name="englishman.fr"/> Despite ''St George''{{'}}s popularity in the public eye, it was also nonetheless controversial; it was also one of the top 10 most complained about adverts reported to the [[Independent Television Commission]] (ITC) in 1996, as 68 complainants citied it as 'insulting and xenophobic'.<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/> The ITC dismissed the complaints, characterising the humour as harmless and likening it to what viewers might see on ''[[Fawlty Towers]]''.<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/> Letters of complaint from French exchange students who did not see the humour in the advertisement were ridiculed in newspaper inserts.<ref name="Brown" />
===Accolades=== ''St George'' was a major success in the industry and won a string of awards.<ref name="campaignlive.co.uk"/> A year after its premiere, Paul McCann of ''The Independent'' said that ''St George'' "has won nearly every advertising award in Britain."<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/> In March 1997, ''St George'' won HHCL Partners the British [[Creative Circle]] award for best advertisement of the year.<ref name="independent.co.uk1">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/tango-advert-is-flavour-of-the-year-1270928.html |title=Tango advert is flavour of the year |first=Marianne |last=Macdonald |date=4 March 1997 |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> The commercial, which was honoured in the platinum section, also won the gold award for best use of humour, as did its sister advert for Tango Apple.<ref name="independent.co.uk1"/> In May, ''St George'' won the [[D&AD]] "Silver Pencil" design award for best advert of the year,<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/> in June, ''St George'' won a [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity|Cannes]] "Gold Lion" award for being a top-tier advertisement,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.advertolog.com/festivals-awards/cannes-lions/cannes-lions-1997/ |title=Cannes Lions 1997 Winners Film : Cannes Lions : Advertising Award Shows |work=advertolog.com |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> and in November 1997, ''St George'' was selected as the grand prize winner from among 7,000 entries from 78 countries at the [[London International Advertising Awards]].<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/> It has also been listed on many industry "advert of the year" lists,<ref name="Independent 18 November 1997"/> and won the "ITV gold award" at the [[British Television Advertising Awards]].<ref name="campaignlive.co.uk"/>
In later times, ''St George'' continued to receive acclaim. In as early as May 1997, ''St George'' was named "ad of the decade" in a survey of readers of ''[[SKY Magazine|Sky Magazine]]'', beating [[Levi]]'s 1995 ''Planet'' advertisement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/sky-readers-choose-blackcurrant-tango-ad-decade/24367 |title=Sky readers choose Blackcurrant Tango as ad of the decade |work=campaignlive.co.uk |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> It has been voted one of the 100 best commercials of all time.<ref name="campaignlive.co.uk"/> Bernice Kanner included ''St George'' in his 1999 list book ''100 Best TV Commercials: And Why They Worked''.<ref name="auto1"/> It won the [[Film Four]] "Best Long Commercial 1956-2001" award in June 2007, whilst Gardner was honoured with the Channel 4 "Director's Cut" Gold Award that same summer, where the advertisement was awarded top honours in the "Vintage Category".<ref name="raygardner.net"/> Ray Gardner later won the "ITV Best Actor In A Commercial" Award for his performance.<ref name="raygardner.net"/> In 2008, advertising industry publication ''[[Campaign (magazine)|Campaign Live]]'' ranked ''St George'' at number 2 in their list of the "Top 10 Funniest TV Ads of All Time".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/865453/ |title=The Top 10 funniest TV ads of all time |work=campaignlive.co.uk |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> In 2013, Ben Tollett and Emer Stamp, joint creative directors of Adam & Eve DDB, included the advert in his list of "3 Great Ads I Had Nothing to Do With", part of a series for ''[[Campaign (magazine)|Campaign Live]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/1392131/3-great-ads-i-nothing-31-ben-priest-tango-lynx-levis |title=3 great ads I had nothing to do with #31: Ben Priest on Tango, Lynx and Levi's |work=campaignlive.co.uk |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref>
At the turn of the millennium, the original [[Hooj Choons|Hooj]]-produced "Hooj Mix" version of "Don't You Want Me", which features in ''St George'' in an early variation of its specially created "'96 Pugilist Mix", was included on several commercially successful, TV-advertised British various artists [[compilation album]]s of popular music featured in acclaimed television advertisements, including [[Virgin Records]]' ''The Best TV Ads...Ever!'' (2000),<ref name="discogs.com1">{{cite web |url=https://www.discogs.com/Various-The-Best-TV-Ads-Ever/release/1659956 |title=Various - The Best TV Ads... Ever! |work=discogs.com |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> which was part of ''[[The Best...Album in the World...Ever!]]'' compilation strand,<ref name="discogs.com1"/> and [[Telstar Records]]'s ''Switched On: The Cool Sound of TV Advertising'' (2001).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.discogs.com/Various-Switched-On-The-Cool-Sound-Of-TV-Advertising/release/2853742 |title=Various - Switched On (The Cool Sound Of TV Advertising) |work=discogs.com |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> The compilations were both released on CD, with ''The Best TV Ads...Ever!'' also being released on cassette, and reached number 10 and 9 in the [[UK Compilation Chart]] respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zobbel.de/ |title=The Official Zobbel Homepage |work=zobbel.de |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref>
==Aftermath== [[File:Stamp of Armenia m141.jpg|thumb|Ray Gardner later appeared in a [[FIFA World Cup 1998]]-tie-in Tango commercial.]] Tango themselves parodied ''St George'' in a HHCL-created advertisement for the orange flavour entitled ''Vote Orange Tango''.<ref name="campaignlive.co.uk1">{{cite web |url=http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/article/63561/britvic-doubles-tango-ad-spend?DCMP=ILC-SEARCH |title=Britvic doubles Tango ad spend |work=campaignlive.co.uk |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> The advertisement, broadcast in March 1997 in the run up to the [[General Election]], takes the form of a mock [[party political broadcast]] where a Tango Orange campaigner criticizes the Apple, Lemon and Blackcurrant variants of the drink individually; his remarks against the blackcurrant flavour see him walk to the roof of a building where the character of Ray Gardner (portrayed by an actor other than Gardner) is still shown expressing his anger against Sebastian, but is clearly exhausted, and ultimately falls into a puddle.<ref name="tvwhirl.co.uk">{{cite web |url=https://www.tvwhirl.co.uk/adverts/adverts-q-z/ |title=TV Whirl - Adverts Q-Z |work=tvwhirl.co.uk |accessdate=12 July 2016}}</ref> The spokesperson criticizes "Blackcurrant Tango" as "stinky wind" and "lets off" an inflatable Ray Gardner.<ref name="tvwhirl.co.uk"/> The advertisement was broadcast in the first ever advert break on [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]].<ref name="campaignlive.co.uk1"/>
Despite his ties to the blackcurrant flavour, Gardner himself later appeared in two advertisements for the orange flavour. The first of these advertisements, ''Clowns'', aired between late 1997 and early 1998 and showed him encouraging a colleague at an event where clowns were being run over by giant trucks.<ref name="tvwhirl.co.uk"/> The advertisement was released to promote the send-away Tango Horn toy, but Tango themselves appeared to deem the advert a failure when a further advertisement in early 1998 humorously dismissed the advert as such.<ref name="tvwhirl.co.uk"/> Gardner's second Tango Orange advertisement aired in mid-1998 during the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]] and showed Gardner advertising a competition to win television sets as part of the brand's World Cup promotions.<ref name="auto2">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FFCVX9IwsAM |title=Sky One Adverts 1998 (9)|first=Adam |last=Beckwith |date=30 March 2011 |accessdate=12 July 2016 |via=YouTube}}</ref> He sported the same uniform as in the start of ''St George''.<ref name="auto2"/> Additionally, Gardner appeared in several wraparound stings (break bumpers) during [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]'s coverage of the World Cup where he is shown exploring [[Paris]] between games, although these stings do not feature Tango branding.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g6GTcI7czkg |title='Blackcurrant Tango' Ray Gardner in France |author=hoopjammer |date=30 November 2012 |accessdate=12 July 2016 |via=YouTube}}</ref>
Despite the success of ''St George'', there were no further advertisements for Tango Blackcurrant, and the flavour was discontinued after several years. Post-''St George'' Tango advertising prior to 2000 focused mainly on the Tango brand as a whole or on the orange and diet orange flavours, and the blackcurrant variant was dropped before their more eclectic advertising would return in the millennium. Tango Blackcurrant was relaunched as an [[Asda]]-exclusive flavour in August 2011 and as a standard flavour in December 2012. Nonetheless, ''St George'' remains the final advertisement for the drink, with Tango having seldom advertised on television in the 2010s.
==See also== *[[Orange Man (advertisement)|''Orange Man'' (advertisement)]] *[[Pipes (advertisement)|''Pipes'' (advertisement)]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5) ([[User:Artix Kreiger|Artix Kreiger]])
revision.text:
{{globalize|date=August 2012|reason=Is this just a UK thing?}}
'''Text roulette''' or '''SMS roulette''' is a game played chiefly by schoolchildren, in which they compose a [[text message]] on their [[mobile phone]] then send it to one of their contacts or a made-up number at random.
==Popular use== [[BBC Radio 1]] disc jockey [[Scott Mills]] makes regular use of [[texting]] as a form of entertainment. In an early form of the game in 2007, he encouraged listeners to send "I love you" messages to a contact at random.<ref>[http://www.mobileindustryreview.com/2007/01/the_i_love_you_text_roulette_game.html The "I Love You" text roulette game], ''Mobile Industry Review'', 15 January 2007. Retrieved 2010-06-09</ref>
In the last episode of Series 3 of [[Channel 4]] sitcom [[The Inbetweeners]], the four main characters play Text Roulette with each other's phones.
==Demographics of users== In 2010, a [[United Kingdom]] survey of people aged 13 to 16 found that one in five had played a variation of the game in which the message must be [[obscene]]. A similar proportion had sent texts to previously unknown mobile numbers typed in at random, asking for the recipient to reply. Motivations included [[loneliness]], "[[fun]]" and [[boredom]], while 9% admitted being [[Truth or Dare?#Similar games|"dared"]] to do it. Of those who had played text roulette, one in three admitted to being in trouble from the recipient.<ref>[http://www.prlog.org/10714067-fifth-of-under-16s-admit-to-risky-random-texting.html Fifth of under 16s admit to risky random texting], rightmobilephone.co.uk, 3 June 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905233538/http://www.prlog.org/10714067-fifth-of-under-16s-admit-to-risky-random-texting.html |date=5 September 2012 }}</ref>
==Dangers== Neil McHugh, who had commissioned the survey, said it showed that young people did not realize the dangers of texting unknown numbers.<ref>[http://thefonecast.com/News/tabid/62/EntryId/2869/Survey-reveals-a-fifth-of-youngsters-play-Text-Roulette.aspx Survey reveals a fifth of youngsters play Text Roulette], The Fonecast, 7 June 2010. Retrieved 2010-06-09</ref>
A writer for business organisation [[ICAEW]] commented that text roulette is a modern variation on an old pattern, i.e. young people finding ways to irritate adults by doing what is forbidden, but raises concerns about [[child safety]].<ref>Sandra Vogel, [http://www.ion.icaew.com/itcounts/20046 SMS roulette, anyone?], ICAEW IT Faculty, 7 June 2010. Retrieved 2010-06-09</ref>
In October 2010, Textslide debuted as an application that enables people to easily and safely engage in SMS conversations with strangers.<ref>[http://mashable.com/2010/10/26/textslide/ Random Chat Service Connects People via SMS], Mashable, Retrieved 2011-02-02</ref>
==See also==
*[[Chatroulette]] *[[Omegle]] *[[Zumbl]]
